importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication reflects the current state of global disaster preparedness and the urgency of implementing early-warning systems in response to escalating extreme weather events in 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline of 2025 highlights a period of intensifying extreme weather events globally, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, which underscores the pressing need for early-warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, particularly in developing nations.
The WMO reports that disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without such systems.
Over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the past 50 years, with 90% of those deaths occurring in developing countries.

While progress has been made—number of countries with multi-hazard early warning systems increased from 52 to 108—the assessment shows half of 62 countries have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is most severe in fragile, conflict-affected areas.
Early warnings are crucial for saving lives and protecting infrastructure as extreme weather intensifies due to climate change.
The WMO emphasizes that early warning leads to early action and calls for global empowerment through better monitoring and alerts.
Progress is being observed in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning websites and standardized alerts.
The collapse of a Swiss mountain glacier in May 2025, predicted through monitoring, led to the evacuation of the village of Blatten, demonstrating the real-world value of early warnings.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), a UN agency, is urging global action to strengthen early-warning systems for extreme weather events, citing that nearly half of all countries lack such systems—especially in developing nations. Over 2 million people have died from weather-related disasters in the past 50 years, with 90% of those deaths occurring in developing countries. While progress has been made in early-warning coverage, assessments show that half of 62 evaluated countries have only basic capacity, and 16% have less. The article highlights real-world examples, such as the successful evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten due to early detection of a glacier collapse in May 2025, and recent extreme weather events in Pakistan, Nigeria, South Korea, southern Europe, and the US, emphasizing the urgent need for global monitoring and response mechanisms. The WMO stresses that early warnings must lead to early action and empower communities, especially in fragile, conflict-affected, and climate-vulnerable regions.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather 'spirals'
